TableContextTimeStampAfterTable: {942=November to February is generally considered the best time to visit Togo as the weather is at its mildest and driest. This is also the time when the harmattan winds blow sand from the Sahara and the air can sometimes be thick with dust. The rainy season, from May to October, brings spectacular rain, sometimes forcing the closure of unsealed roads. Mid-February to April is the hottest period.}
textBeforeTable: Recommended reading Further reading 10. When on community visits or homestays, refrain from giving gifts or money to locals. 9. Please ask and receive permission before taking photos of people, including children. 8. Refrain from supporting businesses that exploit or abuse endangered animals. 7. Shop for locally made products. Supporting local artisans helps keep traditional crafts alive. 6. Learn some local language and don't be afraid to use it - simple greetings will help break the ice. 5. When bargaining at markets, stay calm, be reasonable and keep a smile on your face. It's meant to be fun! 4. Always dispose of litter thoughtfully, including cigarette butts. 3. For environmental reasons, try to avoid buying bottled water. Fill a reusable water bottle or canteen with filtered water. 2. Dress modestly and respectfully. Shoulders to knees should be covered, especially when entering places of worship. 1. Be considerate of Togo’s customs, traditions, religion and culture. Top responsible travel tips for Togo Togo Travel Tips Responsible Travel also provides useful health information: Go to: http://www.who.int/en/ The World Health Organisation Go to: http://www.fco.gov.uk/en/ From UK? Go to: http://travel.state.gov/ From US?
